content.raw:
I'm taking a look at the collisions and trying to figure out why some of them seem to be in a different position from the schematics above. I found some offsets inside collision elements which might be part of the reason. Take a look at these screenshots. (Tip: choose orthogonal view on the top toolbar where you can change the view angle)

![collisions.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/707895362-collisions.png)

![collision2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/2264051415-collision2.png)
content.html: I'm taking a look at the collisions and trying to figure out why some of them seem to be in a different position from the schematics above. I found some offsets inside collision elements which might be part of the reason. Take a look at these screenshots. (Tip: choose orthogonal view on the top toolbar where you can change the view angle)

content.raw: Do we need this offset in the collision? I think it would be better to keep all collisions without offsets, so their poses match the links' inertial properties. What do you think?
content.html: Do we need this offset in the collision? I think it would be better to keep all collisions without offsets, so their poses match the links' inertial properties. What do you think?

content.raw:
I think the `HeadPitch` joint needs a -0.005 offset on Z.

You can add a `<pose>0 0 -0.005 0 0 0</pose>` element to the joint, the pose is with respect to the child link.
content.html:
I think the HeadPitch joint needs a -0.005 offset on Z.

You can add a <pose>0 0 -0.005 0 0 0</pose> element to the joint, the pose is with respect to the child link.

You mean -0.05 offset on Z?

content.raw:
@nima_sh , the changes are looking much better, the model is almost exactly the same as that on the simspark sheet. Basically what I'm doing to find forgotten offsets is to look at the model in Gazebo with an orthogonal view and at the schematics at the same time. You can see a few little parts are still slightly different.

Once the collisions are all matching, we should check the same for the joints.

I hope all these changes make the model behave better with your walking controller!

![collisions2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/A9ekGz/images/893336980-collisions2.png)
content.html:
@nima_sh , the changes are looking much better, the model is almost exactly the same as that on the simspark sheet. Basically what I'm doing to find forgotten offsets is to look at the model in Gazebo with an orthogonal view and at the schematics at the same time. You can see a few little parts are still slightly different.

Once the collisions are all matching, we should check the same for the joints.

I hope all these changes make the model behave better with your walking controller!

content.html: In rev. fba2696 ,I tried to check the model in orthogonal view in order to make it the same as it is in schematics view. Please check also the other parts of the model such as Joints positions and inertias.

content.raw: The height of Simspark model was decreased a bit after its body part properties had been tuned.
content.html: The height of Simspark model was decreased a bit after its body part properties had been tuned.

content.raw: In my test, this set of PID parameters controls the simspark model stably.
content.html: In my test, this set of PID parameters controls the simspark model stably.

content.raw: I could not control the ElbowRoll properly using 1000 hz ODE, so I decrease their PID, it means this joint are not very stiff. if the robot works with 2000 hz ODE, the user can assign the P and D value up to 160 to increase the stiffness of the joint.
content.html: I could not control the ElbowRoll properly using 1000 hz ODE, so I decrease their PID, it means this joint are not very stiff. if the robot works with 2000 hz ODE, the user can assign the P and D value up to 160 to increase the stiffness of the joint.

content.raw: to control the robot, we need high PID feedback gains. Using "Command limit = 1000.0", the robot was not kept upright.
content.html: to control the robot, we need high PID feedback gains. Using "Command limit = 1000.0", the robot was not kept upright.

content.raw: Oops, we totally overlooked the fact that simspark uses +Y for the front instead of +X.
content.html: Oops, we totally overlooked the fact that simspark uses +Y for the front instead of +X.
